bibl.title: Materia Magica. The Archaeology of Magic in Roman Egypt, Cyprus, and Spain
bibl.note: Introduction. - 1. Finding Magic in the Archaeological Record. - 2. Materia Magica. - 3. Identifying the Remains of Magic in the Village of Karanis. - 4. Practitioners and Craft and Amathous, Cyprus. - 5. Three Curses from Empúries and Their Social Implications. - 6. The Archaeology of Magic. - Appendixes: 1. The Excavations at Karanis; - 2. Bones from Karanis Areas 262 and 265. - Bibliography. Index.
bibl.seg: Andrew T. Wilburn, Materia Magica. The Archaeology of Magic in Roman Egypt, Cyprus, and Spain = New Texts from Ancient Cultures.
Ann Arbor, University of Michigan Press, 2012, 8°, xvi-342 pp. et 25 pll. ISBN 978-0-472-11779-6. $80.

Introduction. - 1. Finding Magic in the Archaeological Record. - 2. Materia Magica. - 3. Identifying the Remains of Magic in the Village of Karanis. - 4. Practitioners and Craft and Amathous, Cyprus. - 5. Three Curses from Empúries and Their Social Implications. - 6. The Archaeology of Magic. - Appendixes: 1. The Excavations at Karanis; - 2. Bones from Karanis Areas 262 and 265. - Bibliography. Index.

C.R. par Thomas J. Kraus, TC: A Journal of Biblical Textual Criticism 19 (2014) < http://rosetta.reltech.org/TC/v19/TC-2014-Rev-Wilburn-Kraus.pdf >. - Joseph E. Sanzo, BASP 50 (2013) pp. 353-358. - Steven M. Stannish, AJA 119 (2015) Online Book Reviews < http://www.ajaonline.org/online-review-book/1972 >.
